title: No free content anymore
text: I have been using the calm app since it first came out (around 2018). When it was new, almost everything was free. Over time, the amount of free content has decrease exponentially. Now there is absolutely no free content on the app. Don‚Äôt even bother downloading unless you want to pay or do a free trial. I paid for a subscription for a year back in 2022, and it was helpful for me. I liked the meditation and sleep stories. I decided to cancel my subscription a year later because it was very expensive and I wasn‚Äôt using it enough. Even then, I was still able to do the daily meditations for free.  After downloading the app again today, I was very disappointed to see that there is absolutely no free content anymore. I don‚Äôt like that you are forced into an all or nothing model, especially considering how expensive it is. I wish there was at least tiered access, or that you could pay for access to just your favorite features. I‚Äôll come back to the calm app if I ever get desperate, but I am upset and disappointed that such a great app has put up such a huge pay wall. Especially an app that is supposed to be made to help people with their mental health.

title: Review of Calm
text:
Calm is a meditation, sleep, and relaxation app that varies in material, depending on what an individual wants to focus on. In general, Calm's goal is to help calm the mind and help individuals live happier and healthier lives. As a college student, dealing with stress, anxiety, and problems, sleeping is a regular occurrence. Luckily, Calm has incredibly helpful techniques in combating this. The techniques that Calm uses are grounded in real, reviewed psychological research. 

This app uses mindfulness techniques such as guided meditation, breathing exercises, and soundscapes to help reduce stress. Mindfulness is ‚Äú being aware of one's experience ‚Äúat the moment‚Äù and doing so nonjudgmentally. Calm implements this through its techniques, which are connected to evidence-based approaches such as Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) and Acceptance and Commitment Therapy (ACT), both of which are stated to be overall successful in helping those of all ages with anxiety, trauma, and stressor-related disorders and the top recommended techniques in combating anxiety, trauma, and stress-related disorders. Meditation and breathing techniques are two practices I found extremely helpful in managing my anxiety towards deadlines for assignments and my generalized anxiety. 

Anxiety is also accompanied by physical symptoms such as muscle tension, restlessness, sleep disturbance, and others. These can be combated through Calm techniques by allowing the body to go out of fight-or-flight mode and calm the nervous system. Sleep disturbance specifically is a common symptom of anxiety, as stated in the DSM-5TR; it can include difficulty falling or staying asleep and restless or unsatisfying sleep. Slowing the breath, especially with extended exhales, allows the body to relax, therefore making anxiety and physical symptoms less prominent. Overall, calm techniques are established in research and are well documented for their benefits for symptoms of anxiety.

title: In-depth Calm review
text:
In a turbulent world without many worthwhile virtual mental health apps, this app is worth it. I‚Äôm glad I have it.

Pros:

‚Ä¢Many famous and talented people have been a part of this app‚Äîcelebrities, narrators, mental health professionals. Stories that involve fictional characters and pop culture are fun.

‚Ä¢The main meditation narrators of the Calm app, Tamara, Jeff, Jay, and Mel, make me feel like I have an on-the-go support system. I love that their individual styles of meditation are different. It makes the app feel less cookie-cutter and regimented and I can feel the personalities of the people behind the narration. 

‚Ä¢There‚Äôs a wide selection of meditations and stories to choose from. 

Cons:

‚Ä¢It can be overwhelming at times to find the right meditation for what I‚Äôm feeling because of how big the amount of content is. 

‚Ä¢This app is EXPEEENSIVE.

‚Ä¢I‚Äôm an audio nerd. Super low and high frequencies are jarring and make it HARDER to relax and sleep. Instruments like bells, chimes, cymbals, and sounds like birdsong and rushing water make high-frequency sounds. Instruments like basses, drums, and sounds like whale-song make low-frequency sounds. For sounds made for sleep it‚Äôs important for the audio to be de-essed. Band passes also help.

‚Ä¢The app has recently added ‚ÄúInfinite Ambience‚Äù, ‚ÄúInfinite Guitar‚Äù, ‚ÄúInfinite Piano‚Äù, etc. It might be AI generated. In the spot for where the narrators‚Äô names usually go, it just says ‚ÄúCurated by Calm‚Äù. I think I remember how around a year ago, Calm had something along the lines of a ‚ÄúCustom Sleep Story Maker‚Äù that used Generative AI, but I‚Äôm pretty sure they removed that feature. 

‚Ä¢I don‚Äôt see some meditation and sleep techniques as equal to other ones. These ones seem a bit tacky and trend-y to me: Binaural beats, Bilateral Stimulation, EMDR, anything with Hz (hertz) in its name‚Ä¶It‚Äôs like they‚Äôre trying to use technical sound jargon that I think most people don‚Äôt understand to make it seem fancier and more effective. 

Things I wish the app would add:

‚Ä¢I wish when the app asks ‚ÄúHow are you feeling today?‚Äù, there‚Äôd be more variety and specificity in the emotions you can pick from.

‚Ä¢I wonder if the people behind the app would add something like a ‚Äúworld map of mindfulness‚Äù, so if you want to find meditative practices/skills from one specific area of the world, or hone your meditation skills in a cultural way, you could. 

‚Ä¢Maybe there could be a category of meditation for physical arts and crafts? Mandala making, origami making, things that encourage creativity‚Ä¶

‚Ä¢Dark mode, light mode, and high-contrast UI would be nice.

title: Lifetime subscription that disappeared
text:
I was offered a lifetime subscription option about 4-5 years ago, and I paid for it.  I assumed that the website who had known me for a year, would know I had a lifetime subscription‚Äîbut when I returned to the website a few weeks later, in the middle of the pandemic, there was a paywall that asked for my ‚Äúemailed receipt‚Äù.  I could not find it, and there was no remedy on the website, which just abandoned me after I paid so much.  I didn‚Äôt have the energy to fight about it and stopped using your website for a long time after that.  You should have been able to identify me, as you had always done, but instead, during a time when I really needed your meditations, I was shut out.  That is hard to forget, and whenever I see your paywalls, I am enraged at how you ripped me off and just dropped me during the pandemic time.  I loved Tamara Leavett‚Äôs meditations, and would like to return.  Please honor the lifetime subscription I paid for several years ago. title: Calm was a life saver
text:
I have been a subscriber to Calm almost since its beginning. 
After my husband‚Äôs death, I found myself struggling with falling asleep. I recalled that some of the best sleep I ever had was when I stayed with my grandmother back in the 60s and she would read me to sleep. I thought it would be incredibly helpful. If there was some app that could read me a story and found Calm. When I first signed up there were very few stories, That‚Äôs how long ago I signed up. But that did not matter. Just the sound of a soothing voice, barely perceptible, quietly reading me to sleep was just what I needed.
And now my most favorite thing to listen to at night is calm cathedral. My husband is buried in the Washington National Cathedral. My husband and I attended Tenebrae services and it is a beautiful memory so thank you. Calm has been there for me through some of the hardest times of my life and I‚Äôm so grateful that you have been there.

title: Worth Every Penny!!!
text:
When I first downloaded the app, there were several sleep stories that I were free and were on constant rotation as I fell asleep. Then they changed their pay structure to no longer offer some of the stories free but offer a free trial. 

One sleepless night, I was desperate for my nightly store so I signed for the trial with the intent to cancel before the trial period ended. But I forgot and got charged.

So I just sucked it up and really started to listen to many of the items available. So many more sleep stories, the meditations, etc. Fast forward to a night where the AD/HD was in full force so I decided to see if there was anything for focus and came across a mix from a Ministry of Sound DJ and I am absolutely hooked! I really was able to kick it into a productive mode. Having this alone is worth the annual subscription cost.

Do yourself a favor and invest in yourself!

text:
Years ago, I used Calm but I unsubscribed to cut costs and due to a lack of good programming (for me, anyway).

I received an email to say that if I came back, I would get seven days free so I thought I would try it . However, they charged my card right away. I don‚Äôt like fishy tricks like that.

I have canceled the membership (although I have already been charged for the year) and I will 1)pursue a a through Apple and 2)tell EVERYONE who is considering getting it what happened to me.
